narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strategy in US defense operations, new technology, and the history of strategy in war
How management of business and war overlap. It was hard to pay attention sometimes.

The course mainly focused on frameworks for how to think about the effects of technology on national security organizations. It examined interesting case studies of successful and unsuccessful leveraging of technology in organizations, and provided a framework for how technology can affect organizations and their strategy, particularly in the national security sphere.
Learned a general overview of different technologies and frameworks to explain military and corporate strategy.
Learned so much about US technology in both war and corporations. Military strategy and corporate strategy and their similarities
Learned more about the inner workings of government technology development. This class is especially insightful about the U.S relationship with China concerning technology development.
Learned a lot about the US governments defense policies and how weve enacted them out over the years.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures are interesting but hard to follow. There are only 2 assignments (aside from the midterm and final) so it is hard to know how you are doing in the course. Content is interesting but it is easy to fall behind.
The lecture was a little bit of a ramble and I didn't know what was going on sometimes.

It is really awesome to hear Professor Bracken's insights on many emerging national security topics. The readings were relevant and interesting. The course was a little unstructured, but it allowed opportunities to have discussions and ask questions.

The course covered some very interesting topics, but I felt a lot of class time was occupied with questions from students that didn;t necissarily pertain to th content that was being discussed in class, which became annoying at times.

Very interesting and technical view of management and leadership, crossing lessons from the military and business. As a non-econ yale college student with no experience with business, some of the management/consulting/econ material went way over my head. This material wasn't super central to the course or critical on exams though, so it was ok. The military, tech, history material provided interesting insights into the defense world.
Fantastic course. Bracken is a gem. Could be improved by more feedback throughout the semester to grasp how much you are absorbing but overall great course

Strengths are the professors knowledge. Weaknesses are disorganization. The midterms and finals often have very tricky questions that are hardly discussed in the class. Some of the class terms are very vague without clear definitions.
I loved how we went through each era and discussed the development of tech. I think if we went deeper into present day, I wouldve liked the latter part of the semester a bit more.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class adapted well to the virtual environment, but I believe it would have been much more enjoyable and I would have learned a lot more in a live setting.
Virtual environments are tough
Scheduling virtual office hours was convenient, as well as the ability to stay on and ask questions after class.
as good as it could be
Being able to go back and watch lectures to study for exams was great.
The cold calling helped students stay engaged.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you are interested to learn about Strategy, Technology, and War.
Yes, if you are interested in the material and don't mind a bit of disorganization, it's a great course and relatively straightforward. Workload is manageable and content is interesting.

I would not recommend to an undergraduate looking for an easy course. As someone who took it thinking it was easy, and it is because I took it credit d. He sometimes cold calls in class and if you are unprepared, he knows it. The 2 assignments were super easy but I had no clue what I was doing on the tests. Some of the lectures are pretty cool but then other times I had no clue what was going on.
Yes. I recommend this class to anyone because it covers some really prescient technological and international issues that will be important for years to come.
I would recommend this course to anyone who would like to learn more about technology's impact on military strategy and organizations in general
yes! interesting and low workload, Bracken is great.
Take it Credit/D
Absolutely! So much useful knowledge, presented in an engaging way, from a truly great professor who knows his stuff from personal experience.
I would only recommend you take this class Credit-d-fail, otherwise the assignment grading can be stressful.
Yes, this class offered great insight to how the military is run.

I think that undergrads in particular should make note of the fact that this is taught by an SoM professor - there is a good deal of focus on management techniques and leadership choices, and less focus on the grainier "history" of strategy, technology and war. This was not what I had expected, though it was interesting.
